titleStmt.title: An astrologicall addition, or supplement to be annexed to the late discourse vpon the great coniunction of Saturne, and Iupiter Wherin are particularly declared certaine especiall points before omitted, as well touching the eleuation of one plannet aboue another, with theyr seuerall significations: as touching oeconomical and houshold prouision: with some other iudicials, no lesse profitable. Made and written this last March, by Iohn Haruey, student in Phisicke. Whereunto is adioyned his translation of the learned worke, of Hermes Trismegistus, intituled, Iatromathematica: a booke of especiall great vse for all studentes in astrologie, and phisicke.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: To the Right wor≈øhipful Ma≈øter Iu≈øtice Meade, returning from his Honorable circuite, IOHN HARVEY wi≈øheth long health, and continuall increa≈øe of all prosperitie.
div.p:
MAy it plea≈øe you Right wor≈øhipfull Sir, after ≈øome re≈øpite from ≈øo great bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, as your Honorable circuit carrieth with it, to accept fauourablie of the affectionate minde of a yong ≈øcholler, I will pre≈øume in ≈øtead of the be≈øt well-come-home, that my poore ≈øtudy can pre≈øently afoord, to pre≈øent your good woor≈øhip with a briefe A≈øtrologicall exerci≈øe, which I lately vndertoke vppon this occa≈øion. Hauing ≈øundry times peru≈øed the A≈øtrologicall di≈øcour≈øe touching the great Coniunction of Saturne & Iupiter, publi≈øhed the la≈øte Ianuary by my brother Richard, and therein noting by the way ≈øome wante of certaine nece≈ø≈øarie „Äà‚óä„Äâ
profitable Iudicials, which ≈øeemed con
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ nient to be added for the more expres and particular di≈øcu≈øsing of ≈øome pointes‚ñ™
generally, and that diligently too, by him con≈øidered, but not ≈øo narrowly, and preci≈øely examined, as they might haue been, (which was not my opinion only, but the iudgement of ≈øome his learned welwillers, and great commenders otherwi≈øe) I re≈øolued in the end to ea≈øe him of that labour, knowing him≈øelfe to bee otherwi≈øe bu≈øied vpon more ≈øpecial and nece≈ø≈øary occa≈øion. Which I was the more willing to enterprize, for the≈øe foure cau≈øes. Fir≈øt, to ≈øatisfie the demaunds and de≈øires of tho≈øe his lerned friendes: then, to ≈øtoppe the mouthes of his enuious & carping enemies: thirdly, to benefit ≈øuch of our CouÃÑtrey generally, as by prouidence are de≈øirous to worke their owne commoditie and ≈øafetie: and la≈øt of all, to practi≈øe my ≈øelfe particularlie in ≈øuch an exerci≈øe, as was ≈øo profitable for an Vniuer≈øitie man, ≈øo conuenient for a Student in Philo≈øophy, & the Mathematicks, and finally, ≈øo agreeable to that ≈øtudie and profe≈øsion, whereunto partly by my naturall di≈øpo≈øition I was inclyned, and partly vpon farther adui≈øe of my friendes, and ≈øome priuate con≈øultation of mine owne, I had wholy betaken, and as it were betroathed my ≈øelfe. Be≈øides which cau≈øes, the verie worthines and dignitie of the Arte it ≈øelfe, not only in re≈øpect of the high and
heauenly matter, or obiect thereof, according to the diuine ver≈øes of Doctor Antony Myzaldus.

But al≈øo, euen for the other three Logike cau≈øes, the efficient, the forme, and the end or finall cau≈øe; might as wel commend this exerci≈øe vnto me, as it hath done many the like, nay many for all excellencie both of qualitie and quantitie, farre vnlike vnto other manner of men, then I either pre≈øently am, or am euer like to be. For the fir≈øt author and principall efficient, what enemie to A≈øtrologie can deny, but God him ≈øelfe, po≈øuit duo magna luminaria, & ≈øtellas in firmamento caeli, as Moy≈øes writeth in the beginning of Gene≈øis: Why? vt diuiderent diem, ac noctem, & e≈ø≈øent in ≈øigna, & tempora, & dies, & annos. In quae ≈øigna? nimirum in ≈øigna naturalium euentuum, vt futurae pe≈øtilentiae, belli, & pacis, penuriae, & abundantiae, caeteror√∫mque ≈øimilium phy≈øicorum effectuum, as a learned wryter very well in my ≈øimple iudgement expoundeth that place of Moy≈øes. Be≈øides, who knoweth not that all good giftes, and all good artes descend from aboue, and had their originall from the father of light? Whereupon Melancthon
in his preface to Purbachius, his A≈øtrologicae Theoricae, not only concludeth generally of all liberall Artes, Cum Artes Dei munus ≈øint, non defuturus e≈øt Deus his, qui ip≈øius dona tuentur, & con≈øeruare ≈øtudent: with this comfortable addition: Erunt & fatae ip≈øa aliquando Artibus aequiora: but al≈øo particularlie inueigheth again≈øt all ≈øuch Epicures, and contemners, as ≈øet them ≈øelues again≈øt the mo≈øt heauenly and diuine knowledge of A≈øtrologie. In which Inuectiue, he is ≈øo earne≈øtly bent again≈øt them, that he breaketh foorth into the≈øe vehement ≈øpeeches. Epicureos illos, qui neque pulcherrimos motus caele≈øtium corporum admirantur, neque cognitionem eorum vtilem e≈ø≈øe contendunt, ne hominum quidem appellatione dignos e≈ø≈øe iudico. His rea≈øon is. Etenim non ≈øolum bellum gerunt cum humana natura, quae praecipue ad has diuinas res a≈øpiciendas condita e≈øt, ≈øed etiam
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ
≈øunt. Voluit enim Deus horum mirabilium Cur≈øuum, ac caele≈øtium virium notitiam, ducem nobis e≈ø≈øe ad diuinitatis cognitionem. And againe ≈øhortlie after he addeth: Haec ≈øi quis arroganter conteninit, naturae ≈øuae immanitatem prodit, non aliter atque Cyclops apud Homerum, qui negat ≈øe vllos vereri Deos. So that Melancthon, is not afraide to condemne them euen for Epicures, and Athei≈øtes, that condemne this mo≈øt goodly and godly Science. And
as for our ≈øecundarie Authors and founders, what two more famous Princes among≈øt the auncient Aegyptians, and Romanes, then Hermes Tri≈ømegi≈øtus, and Numa Pompilius? Or what two more excellent kinges among≈øt the later Aegyptians and Aragonians, then Ptolomey, and Alphon≈øus? The re≈øt for breuitie I ouerpa≈ø≈øe, ≈øauing that I mu≈øt not omitte the poets honorable te≈øtimonie, as well of them, as of the forenamed:
Faelices animae, quibus haec cogno≈øcere primum,
Inque domos ≈øuperas ≈øcandere cura fuit.
Credibile e≈øt illos pariter vitij≈øque, ioci≈øque
Altius humanis exerui≈ø≈øe Caput.

And ≈øo forward, till at la≈øt, he geueth them this marueylous commendation, taken from their marueylous effectes:
Admouere oculis di≈øtantia ≈øydera no≈øtris,
Aethera
que ingenio ≈øuppo≈øuere ≈øuo.

Now if we con≈øider either the internall forme of the Arte it ≈øelfe, or the externall forme of our cheefe≈øt Artificers: can it be gaine≈øaide, but the one is heauenlie, like the matter: the other, e≈øpeciallie, in the Greeke and Latin toungs, as di≈øtinct and Methodicall, as was to be found in any Philo≈øopher, or Mathematician
of the ≈øame ages? And nowe of late Adolphus Scribonius of Marpurgh in Germanie, in his ≈ømall Tractate, intituled I≈øagoge Sphaerica, hath ≈øomewhat reformed the Artificiall maner and order of our more auncient A≈øtrologers, according to the exact and exqui≈øite rules of Ramus methode, howbeit he doeth not ≈øo farre go beyond them in maner, but he commeth as farre behind them in matter: as euery learned A≈øtrologer mu≈øt needes confe≈ø≈øe. La≈øt of all, touching the end, or finall cau≈øe of A≈øtrologie, he can do very little, God wot, that is not able to mainteine the ende thereof to be partly diuine, and common with other Artes, partly humane, and proper vnto it ≈øelfe. The diuine or common ende, is the glorie of God; the humane, or proper ende, to do good in the world, by ≈øuch predictions, and diuinations, as the principles and rules of this Art truly deliuered, and rightly vnder≈øtoode, doo afford: fir≈øt, in forewarning what euils and mi≈øchiefes are like to en≈øue: and then in foretelling, what goods and commodities may be reaped by timely proui≈øion: for the better auoiding of the one by preuention, and the more certeine enioying of the other by foreca≈øt: according to tho≈øe notable ver≈øes of the learned Poet:
Illic A≈øtra, polos, caelum, ≈øeptem
que planetas
Con≈øulit A≈øtrologus: terri≈ø
que reportat eorum
Concilium, hinc armans illas, firman≈ø
que caducae
Contra caele≈øtes Iras, Superum
que furorem.
Which finall end, togither with the other three rea≈øonable, and logike cau≈øes, beeing rea≈øonablie and logikelie con≈øidered, I can not ≈øee howe the worthines or dignitie of this Arte, can any way be impeached, without great indignitie offered therevnto. Vpon indifferent examination of which cau≈øes, whereby he principally mea≈øureth the worthines or vnworthines of euery good or bad thing, my brother Gabriel, was much the better content, as he hath him ≈øelfe confe≈ø≈øed, that both my brother Richard and I ≈øhould take the≈øe paines in Iudiciarie A≈øtrologie, which otherwi≈øe he had rather we ≈øhould haue be≈øtowed vpon the more popular and ordinarie ≈øtudies of the right morall and naturall Philo≈øophie, Arithmetike, Geometrie, and Co≈ømographie, with the fir≈øt principles, and mo≈øt nece≈ø≈øarie precepts of A≈øtronomie, ≈øo farre as fetting their grounds from infallible experience, they extende but to the ob≈øeruation of the place, magnitude, and motion of euery ≈øtarre, with their whole number, as partly by Geometricall men≈øuration, and partly by Arithmeticall ≈øupputation,
both ≈øeuerally & iointly they haue beene de≈øcried, to the altitude or depre≈øsion of ech of them, who≈øe farne≈ø≈øe & neerenes either vnto vs, or among≈øt them ≈øelues, is ≈øo exactly determinable by the v≈øe of the A≈øtrolabe, either Quadrant, as Ptolomeis was, or orbicular, as ours now v≈øeth to be: to the de≈øcription, & determination of times, which auaileth ≈øo much, a≈øwell to the exerci≈øe of Husbandrie, as to diuers other expedient and nece≈ø≈øary v≈øes: to the ≈øituation of places, in declaring the longitude, latitude, and di≈øtance of euery place, which is ≈øo great an helpe in Co≈ømographie, and ≈øo ≈øpecially needefull for direction in Hydographie or Nauigation, being otherwi≈øe de≈øtitute of all certentie in the midde≈øt of ≈øo many and huge ieopardies: or finally to the intimation of any ≈øuch meere A≈øtronomicall experiments, without mixture of any Iudicials, either Arabian, or other, pretending any prediction of things to come, or di≈øcouerie of hidden & ≈øecret matters. So that con≈øidering the premi≈ø≈øes, and therevnto referring that mo≈øt notable iudgement of Melancton, vpon Ptolomeis Magna Syntaxis, where he ≈øaith: Explodenda e≈øt illa Epicurea Philo≈øophia, quae tollit finales ≈øtellarum cau≈ø≈øas, & affirmat earum omnes naturas
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ : & ≈øi ≈øint finales cau≈ø≈øae caeterarum
rerum, cur non dicemus etiam e≈ø≈øe pulcherrimorum corporum, & perpetuarum Motuum? Certitudo in motu, artem opi≈øicis indicat; Ars con≈øilium, ac cau≈øam finalem nece≈ø≈øari√≤ complectitur: vnde & ≈øtellae haud dubi√® ≈øuos habent tum effectus, tum ≈øignificationes in elementis, & in ijs, quae inde gignuntur: vt manife≈øta experientia, & omnibus ≈øaeculis con≈øentiens, te≈øtatur congre≈ø≈øus ≈øiccorum ≈øyderum magnas ≈øiccitates, humidorum, humidas tempe≈øtates efficere: and ≈øo foorth, till he proceedeth thus farre: At caele≈øtes hae ≈øignificationes non modo magnas mutationes tempe≈øtatum, ≈øed etiam ciuilium rerum denunciant; vt o≈øtendunt euentus, qui comitantur Eclyp≈øes, & magnas Planetarum coniunctiones: nec illa ≈øigna vllo modo pugnant cum religione, cum Deus ea & propo≈øuerit, & gubernet. For the≈øe (I ≈øay) and the like effectuall con≈øiderations, my brother Gabriel, beeing of him ≈øelfe otherwi≈øe affected, hath not di≈øliked either of my brother Richards, or of my exerci≈øe in this kinde. Wherevppon as he at the length was the boulder to dedicate his A≈øtrologicall Di≈øcour≈øe vnto my Lorde the Bi≈øhop of London, who accepted mo≈øt fauourablie and curteou≈ølie thereof; ≈øo am I al≈øo the rather encouraged to direct this my ≈ømall Treati≈øe folowing, beeing a ≈øupplement of the ≈øaide Di≈øcour≈øe,
vnto your good wor≈øhip, who I hope will likewi≈øe vouch≈øafe it either the ≈øame, or the like fauourable acceptation. Neither dur≈øt he then, or I now, haue pre≈øumed vpon any ≈øuch dedication vnto ≈øuch per≈øonages, but after good aduice and deliberation, as well touching the premi≈ø≈øes ≈øpecially, as generally touching the more ample auouchment of the whole Arte, being ≈økilfully handled, di≈øcreetly ordered, and lawfully practi≈øed, as it ought to be: which being more fully and per≈øwa≈øiblie pro≈øequuted by my brother Richard in his ≈øecond Di≈øcour≈øe, entreating of Februarie Newes, and by the way defending both the right Iudicials of A≈øtrologie, in genere, and his owne particular Iudicials concerning the effects of this great April coÃÑiunction, in ≈øpecie: I hope there ≈øhall not here neede anie farther Apologie either of his fact, or mine: Con≈øidering withal, what good and effectuall cau≈øes moued vs, as well to the vndertaking of the priuate exerci≈øe, as to the aduenturing of the publique Dedication vnder the names of ≈øo graue, and ≈øo well reputed per≈øonages, for their calling and wi≈ødome. For my ≈øelfe, I am to adde, that not only the right wor≈øhipful e≈øtimation and account of your name, and honorable Commonwelth vertues (which
notwith≈øtanding are of ≈øo great reputation here in E≈ø≈øex, where my mo≈øt abode ≈øince Michae≈ømas la≈øt, vpon ≈øome occa≈øion hath been) hath cau≈øed me to pre≈øent this A≈øtrological Treati≈øe, together with my Tran≈ølation of Hermes mo≈øt famous Iatromathematica vnto your good wor≈øhip, but al≈øo certaine other re≈øpectes, no le≈ø≈øe effectuall. If I had been ignorant before, yet ≈øince my late continuaunce here, I coulde not but learne how ≈øingular account you make of all good learning, what e≈øpeciall great fauour you extend towards the ≈øtudious and learned; and la≈øtly, how ready and de≈øirous you are to defend and maintaine both the one and the other, eyther by priuate, or publicke patronage. Which very affection of yours, ≈øo euidently declared by ≈øo many actuall ≈øignifications therof, might of it ≈øelfe, without farther rea≈øon, ≈øufficiently encourage me vnto this dedication. But I cannot forgette my Brother Gabriels report of the bountifull and courteous entertainment which it plea≈øed you aboue three yeeres ≈øince to geue vnto him, and the Oxforde Preacher, his Companion at that time, being both but ≈øtrangers vnto you. Which entertainment I heard him both then, and ≈øince, much coÃÑ mende, as well for your wor≈øhipfull and
rare courte≈øie, extended towardes them, partly by familiar di≈øcour≈øe vpon ≈øome chiefe pointes of learning, and partly by manife≈øt declaration of your good liking, & welwi≈øhing otherwi≈øe, as for the greatnes of the cheare, choi≈øe of the companie, manner of welcome, and ≈øuch like. Which he ≈øaide could not choo≈øe but proceede of a liberall, and wor≈øhipfull minde, of the wi≈øer, and learneder ≈øort: as no doubt it did. Be≈øide this, I haue lately heard it credibly reported here in Walden, that your good wor≈øhippe ≈øhould like very wel, and commend of my brother Richards A≈øtrologicall Di≈øcour≈øe, with farther mention, not only of my brother Gabriel, to his e≈øpeciall commendation and credit, but euen of my poore ≈øelfe too. All which cau≈øes, and rea≈øons concurring, as they doo, how much were I to be blamed, if I ≈øhould make any other choi≈øe for this my fir≈øt Dedication, then of your good wor≈øhippe? To whom my onely ≈øuite, and humble reque≈øt is, that it may plea≈øe you to accept fauourablie of ≈øo ≈ømal a te≈øtimonie of my duetifull good will, and heartie affection, vntill God ≈øhall enhable me to make ≈øome rea≈øonable amends with ≈øome other of greater ≈øhewe, and more importance. Which I tru≈øt wil not be long, if my
≈øtudie in the Mathematikes and Phy≈øike, may haue that ≈øucce≈ø≈øe, which I hope in God it ≈øhall. In the meane time, pre≈øuming in ≈øome part, of your wonted goodne≈ø≈øe, and fauour, and crauing pardon in the re≈øt, I mo≈øt humblie commend your wor≈øhippe to almightie God. This fir≈øt of Aprill. 1583.

div.head: AN ASTROLOGICAL ADdition, or ≈øupplement, to be annexed to the late Di≈øcour≈øe, vpon the great Coniunction, of Saturne and Iupiter: Newlie ≈øent by Iohn Haruey, to his wor≈øhipfull, and beloued Brother, M. Gabriell Haruey.
div.p:
GOod Brother, vnder≈øtanding here in Walden, how de≈øirous ≈øome haue been both in London and Cambridge, to e≈øpie a hole in my brother Richards cote, and knowing his own bu≈øine≈ø≈øe otherwi≈øe at this pre≈øent, I haue aduentured to adde vnto his A≈øtrological Di≈øconr≈øe, what I (vpoÃÑ ≈øome coÃÑference) thought, might rea≈øonablie be demaunded, as therein requi≈øite. My meaning is not to perfect Apelles picture, or to teach him, of whom I may learne: but to doe as much for him in his wante of ley≈øure (≈øo farre as my reading will extend) as I would wi≈øh him to doe for me vpon like occa≈øion. Whereunto I was the readier, in re≈øpect of that v≈øe and fruite that I might priuately reape of ≈øo ≈øchollarlie and philo≈øophicall an exerci≈øe. Which agreeing, as it doth with that finall profe≈ø≈øion, which I haue already after ≈øome deliberation, made choi≈øe of, cannot (I conceiue) but be a very profitable
and auailable exerci≈øe for me. It is no great matter that my yeares can yet affoorde: I ea≈øily graunt, (notwith≈øtanding more reading in the Mathematicks, and e≈øpecially in A≈øtrologie, then euery one knoweth of, that as the Poet ≈øaith, Adhuc mea me≈øsis in herba e≈øt. But as my ≈øpring beginneth now with the Spring, ≈øo I hope by Gods grace, to ≈øee the harue≈øt, that ≈øhall yeald and bring forth my harue≈øt. If I procead not, the fault is only mine own: if I ≈øuccead, I mu≈øt be thankfull fir≈øt vnto God, & then vnto tho≈øe, whom it hath plea≈øed him to make my founders, and chieflie your ≈øelfe. But that I may the better proceede, and ≈øucceed, as well in this briefe Treati≈øe now, as hereafter in my other larger exerci≈øes, I am taught of our great Arabian A≈øtrologers, to begin, go forwarde, and end, with God: a≈ø≈øuring my ≈øelf of the vndouted certaintie of the auncient Greeke ver≈øe:
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ .

Which being my principal & final ground, I doubt not but I may as ≈øafely, and lawfully exerci≈øe my ≈øelfe in the practi≈øe of this ≈øtudie, as of any other liberall Arte. How≈øoeuer ≈øome through ignoraunce, and ≈øome through other ≈øini≈øter cau≈øes conceiue ami≈ø≈øe thereof: contrarie to Saynt Ambro≈øe, Theodoretus, the famous auncient bi≈øhop Thomas Aquinas, Ioannes Hi≈øpalen≈øis, ≈øometime
a reuerend bi≈øhopp in Spaine, Lucas Gauricus, a learned Italian bi≈øhop, Ioannes Ganiuetus, Michael a Petra ≈øancta, & Franci≈øcus Iunctinus, Doctors of diuinitie, with diuers other of like grauitie and reputation, who haue been great fauourers, and practi≈øers of the ≈øame, wel and orderly v≈øed. I would to God I were but worthie to carrye the bookes of ≈øome, that haue trauailed this way: and namely of tho≈øe, whome my brother Richard namely commendeth for their ≈øingular ≈økil, and paines taking in this facultie. Vnto whom I may trulie adde, Septimius Seuerus, Ve≈øpa≈øianus, Hadrianus, Athel≈øtane, a noble king of England, who≈øe A≈øtrological worke, as you do be≈øt remember, is mentioned by Ramus in his Scholae Mathematicae; Leopoldus Au≈øtriacus, Laurentius de Medicis, & certaine other mo≈øt worthy Emperors, Kings, and Princes; to let pa≈ø≈øe Hermes Tri≈ømegi≈øtus, Numa Pompilius, Bladud, one of our fir≈øt Briti≈øh Kinges, and ≈øuch other of greate≈øt auncientie. Neither can I mu≈øe and maruell inough, that any learned Diuines ≈øhould bande again≈øt the right v≈øe of A≈øtrologie: con≈øidering what my brother hath alleadged, ≈øpecially out of Melancthon. Whereunto may be adioyned that notable iudgement and autoritie of Dauid Chitraeus, deliuered by him in a Treati≈øe of his, intituled,
De ≈øtudio Theologiae rect√® inchoando: where Chitraeus wordes are verbatim the≈øe: Arithmaticae, & A≈øtronomiae cognitio, in Eccle≈øia, ad doctrinae de Anno, & Calendarii con≈øeruationem, nece≈ø≈øaria e≈øt. Non enim initio mundi, non Exordia, & propagatio Eccle≈øiae, non ≈øeries diuinarum patefactionum, non or do ImperioruÃÑ, non tempora aduentus Chri≈øti in carnem, & ad iudicium, non tempora quibus praecipui doctores Eccle≈øiae vixerunt, & maximae res in Eccle≈øia ge≈øtae ≈øunt, non ratio celebrandi Pa≈øchatis Iudaici, non magnitudo miraculi, quo Sol patiente Chri≈øto ob≈øcuratus e≈øt, non talia multa cogitari & intelligi, ≈øine numeratione Annorum, & initijs doctrinae A≈øtronomicae po≈ø≈øunt. A ≈øufficient rea≈øon, a man would thinke: which neuerthele≈ø≈øe he al≈øo confirmeth, and ratifyeth, fir≈øt diuino, and then, humano te≈øtimonio, after this maner: Ideo Deus ip≈øe in prima ≈øtatim ≈øacrae Scripturae pagina, iubet nos ≈øpacia motuum Solis, & Lunae, qui dierum, men≈øium, & annorum metas con≈øtituunt, & maxim√® omnium illu≈øtria Dei, & prouidentiae diuinae ≈øigna ≈øunt, ob≈øeruare. Vere enim, vt Plato ait, grati≈øsima, & omnium dulci≈øsima de Deo fama, in a≈øtris, & doctrina a≈øtrorum ≈øpar≈øa e≈øt. In con≈øideration of which re≈øpects, the forenamed Iohannes Hi≈øpalen≈øis
in his prologe to Albumazar the Arabian, interpreteth him ≈øelfe and other A≈øtrologers thus. Cum dicimus Planetam aliquem, malum futurum prae≈øignare, nihil aliud ≈øentimus, ni≈øi quod ≈øui Creatoris mandato vt creaturae in≈øeruientes, eius prae≈øcientiam imitando hominem ip≈øum malum nobis o≈øtendunt. To which effect al≈øo, the fore≈øaid Ioannes Ganiuetus, in the ≈øeuenth chapter of his fourth Difference, determineth in the≈øe wordes: Culpando planetarum ≈øignificata, etiam pro certo diuinam ≈øtatim culpamus prouidentiam. Nihil enim aliud planetae, qu√†m quod Deus praeuiderit, aut praede≈øtinauerit, ≈øignificant. Which is likewi≈øe confirmed by Ioannes Picus Mirandula, in the fir≈øt booke and ≈øecond chapter of his Heptaplus, in following the≈øe two autenticall‚ñ™ Maximes: Nihil agunt cau≈øae naturales, quod non diuinae Artis ordo praeceperit. And, Omne opus Naturae, e≈øt opus intelligentiae. Whereof the fir≈øt he alleadgeth as a ≈øound principle of the diuine Platoni≈øtes; the ≈øecond, as a common Rule of the Perepatecians, both theron grounding a di≈øtinction of cau≈øes, the one exemplaris in God him ≈øelfe, the other organica, in his In≈øtrumentes and creatures. Which con≈øiderations being pre≈øuppo≈øed as they ought, and laid down for our very fir≈øt and principall foundations, let me
≈øee, I ≈øay not what Diume, but what diuinitie maketh again≈øt vs? e≈øpecially if withall the autoritie of Gemma Fri≈øius may be takeÃÑ, who in his Preface to Stadius Ephemerides, auoucheth this Arte to be ≈øo certainlie true, and infallible, that he is not afeard to attribute euen, veraÃÑ & nece≈ø≈øariam „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ
thereunto. To which purpo≈øe I could likewi≈øe apply diuers other as credible te≈øtimonies, & namely of the forenamed Michael a Petra ≈øancta, Iouianus Pontanus, Iacobus GohoÃÑhemes O≈øtofrancus, and Lucius Bellantius Senen≈øis. But the legitimation of liberall ≈øciences, and as wel of this, as of any other, is to be auowed rather by the generall practi≈øe of all ages, then by any ≈øuch particular proofe: and therfore hauing as wel herein, as in the whole cour≈øe of the Tractate following, added ≈øomething to my brothers di≈øcour≈øe, I will forthwith proceede to the like Supplement of the entire matter it ≈øelfe: reque≈øting therein the ≈øame fauourable patience, which you extended to his larger Di≈øcour≈øe. I mu≈øt craue pardon for the forme and ≈øtile, wherwith I am not yet ≈øufficiently acquainted. If the matter only be an≈øwerable to your expectation, I ≈øhall thinke my labor well be≈øtowed. But how≈øoeuer it falleth out, I hope, In rebus magnis ≈øit volui≈ø≈øe ≈øatis, will rea≈øonablie ≈øerue for my purgation.
Better a common excu≈øe then none at all. Thus pre≈øuming the be≈øt, I am bould to offer you the A≈øtrologicall Treati≈øe following: not plea≈øing my ≈øelfe therin, but de≈øirous to plea≈øe you, and plea≈øure other therewith.

div.head: A Note or Table of the ≈øeuerall Fortitudes and Debilities of the Planets, according to their ≈øituation and placing in the former Figure.
The order of the Planets, as they are either ≈øtrong, or weake; more familiarly expre≈ø≈øed for the common capacitie of the vn≈økilfuller ≈øorte.
div.p: BY this di≈øtribution, or Table may ea≈øily be gathered what Planets are ≈øtrongly ≈øituated in the prefixed figure of the Heauens: as al≈øo what Planets are f√©eble and weak in the ≈øame. Now it followeth that w√©e lykewi≈øe conferre them among≈øt them≈øelues, accordinge to the true and exact number of their Fortitudes & Debilities, that it may yet more manife≈øtly and ≈øen≈øibly appear which of them are mo≈øt ≈øtronge and fortunate, and which againe mo≈øt weake and infortunate, and how one as it were lineally ≈øucc√©edeth another in ≈øtrength and power.

Fir≈øt the amiable Planet Venus among≈øt all the other Planets is ≈øimply mo≈øt ≈øtronge and fortunate in the former cele≈øtiall ≈øcheme: For if the number of her debilities be ≈øubtrated from the ≈øumme of her fortitudes, there till remayne 13. te≈øtimonies of ≈øtrength, which no other Planet obtayneth in this Figure. Notwith≈øtandinge ≈øh√©e is ≈øomewhat weakened by certaine other accidentall Debilities,
then are yet named: for ≈øhe is a≈ø≈øociated with the Dragons tayle, which as Guido Bonatus well te≈øtifieth, Cum bonis mala e≈øt, & boni bonitatem minuit. Al≈øo not pa≈ø≈øing two houres before ≈øhe was oppo≈øite to the Moone, ex Diametro, b√©eing ≈øituated in quarta coeli ma≈øculina, ≈øuper terram in die. Be≈øide that, in ≈øigno ma≈øculino, contrarie to her owne proper nature. And la≈øtly, Septentrionalis A≈øcendens, which do all ≈øomewhat a≈ø≈øuage and abate her courage: wherefore her ≈øignifications can not be altogither ≈øo fortunate and effectual, as otherwi≈øe they might, and would haue b√©en.

2 Then the two ≈øuperior Planets conioyned Saturne and Iupiter ≈øucc√©eds, which are both very ≈øtrong and valerous in compari≈øon of their debilities, becau≈øe their fortitudes are not only equiualent: but euen as many mo in nuÃÑber as their debilities. For Saturns te≈øtimonies of ≈øtrength are 18. his debilities but 9. So likewi≈øe are the fortitudes of Iupiter 18. his debilities but 9. Wherefore Saturne and Iupiter ≈ø√©eme equally matched in power and ≈øtrength: but in re≈øpect of Circum≈øtances, I take Iupiter to be the ≈øtronger of both, which being generallie taken, is a good and laudable token, but particularlie di≈øcu≈ø≈øed, not ≈øo good; as ≈øhall more plainly be declared hereafter.

3 Mercurie is next in ≈øtrength, although in verie d√©ed his ≈øtrength be rather weaknes, then ≈øtrength, and little or nothing at all to ≈øpeake of. For albeit his vertues are more in number by two, then his debilities, yet he is not ≈øo much exalted by tho≈øe two te≈øtimonies, as he is depre≈ø≈øed by his A≈øcen≈øion in Meridiem, by b√©eing, in ≈øigno mali planetae, & in cadenti loco caeli, which on the contrarie ≈øide, doo much increa≈øe his euill influence, and make him more infortunate. Nam ≈øicut ≈øignum turbat Domum, ita Domus turbat ≈øignum, & ≈øignum Planetam. An approued rule.

4 Now as concerning Mars, Sol, and Luna, they are very weake and infortunate in the prefixed ≈øcheme, but e≈øpecially Sol: For whereas the debilities of Luna are but a ≈øewe moe, and the debilities of Mars ≈øcar≈øe halfe ≈øo many mo as his fortitudes: the detrimentes of the Sun are in number full as many mo as his incremeÃÑts, which proportion mu≈øt nedes greatly increa≈øe and augment the ≈øtraunge euents threatned by this corporall coniunction of Saturne and Iupiter in the eighte hou≈øe.

5 Finally, Pars Fortunae, that is, the place of Heauen, wherein the rayes of the Sunne and Moone doo concurre or m√©ete, is fortunately appoynted in this Figure,
being fortified with no le≈ø≈øe then 16. vertues Neuerthele≈ø≈øe, Iupiter Dominus Domus Partis Fortunae, being placed in domo magn ‚Ä¢
infortunij, & etiam mortis, and there accompanied with Infortunium Maius, dot ‚Ä¢
≈øomewhat decrea≈øe the good Fortune of Pars Fortunae; And ≈øo much the rather, becau≈øe Pars Fortunae it ≈øelf is ≈øituated in the 8. ≈øigne although notwith≈øtandinge it bee re≈øidente it the 7. hou≈øe, yea & it is very nigh the cu≈øpis of the 8. hou≈øe too, for it wanteth but onely too Degr√©es of the ≈øame.
div.trailer: And thus much generally touching the true con≈øtitution of the Planets, at that Moment.

div.p:
Now to de≈øcend more particularly vnto the pre≈øent matter; The Dignities & Debilities of Saturne & Iupiter, according to their ≈øituation in the cele≈øtiall figure at the time of their Coniunction, being already ≈øet downe; that the true effectes and operations of their m√©eting may the more manife≈øtly appeare, it followeth that w√©e con≈øider which of them is eleuated and exalted aboue the other, at that in≈øtant. For Ptolomey in his 63. verbo Centiloquij, deliuereth this Maxime. Oportet a≈øpicere in Coniunctione Saturni & Iouis in eodem Minuto ad eleuationem vnius eorum ≈øuper alterum, & iudica cum fortitudine
eius, ≈øcilicet eleuati in hoc mundo, & ≈øimiliter fac in 20. re≈øiduis CoÃÑiuÃÑctionibus. Vpon which notable place of Ptolomey, his Interpreter Albohazen Haly commenteth thus: Eleuatio planetae ≈øuper planetam e≈øt, vt ≈øit remotio ab Auge Circuli ≈øui breuis, minor remotione alterius ab Auge Circuli ≈øui breuis, & ille dicitur eleuatus ≈øuper alterum. Where I gather that per remotioneÃÑ ab Auge, he vnder≈øtaÃÑdeth their di≈øtance from that poynt of their exceÃÑtrick, which is farde≈øt di≈øtant from the Center of the earth. And when he ≈øaith, parui circuli, he meaneth, as I ≈øuppo≈øe, their ≈øeueral Epicicle, affirming ye he which is neare≈øt the ≈øummitie of his Epicicle, is eleuated aboue the other, which is farder remoued from ye ≈øummity of his Epicicle. Marry this mu≈øt be found out & knoweÃÑ, per vtriu≈ø
que
ArgumentuÃÑ aequatuÃÑ, which Argument wil ≈øoon euidently declare, & certainly demon≈øtrate the ≈øame. Wherfore to omitte now for breuities ≈øake, Minuta differentiaruÃÑ cuÃÑ partibus proportionalibus, and ≈øo foorth, for≈øomuch as they make no ≈øen≈øible difference, I will directly & compendiou≈øly, by Arithmetical, & A≈øtronomical ≈øupputation, ≈øet down the true Argument of ech of them, as I haue purpo≈øely calculated the ≈øame for that very time: and briefly collected them in the two ≈øhort Notes, or tables following.

div.p:
By which calculation I gather fir≈øt, that Saturne is de≈øcending in his Eccentrike, or Deferent; becau≈øe his Centrum aequatum
‚Ä¢ s, ab vno gradu in ≈øex ≈øigna; and that Iupiter on the other ≈øide is A≈øcending in his Eccentrike or Deferent, becau≈øe his Centrum
‚Ä¢ equatum, is aboue ≈øixe ≈øignes. But for≈øomuch as Argumentum aequatum Saturni is nigher 0. grade, 0. minut, then ArgumentuÃÑ equatuÃÑ Iouis, (for when the Argumentum equatuÃÑ of a planet is 0. G. 0. M. he is, in ≈øummitate Epicicli) I take Saturne to be nigher he ≈øummity of his Circle, & con≈øequently to the eleuated aboue Iupiter, ≈øecundum AugeÃÑ, by rea≈øon of his proximitie to his Aux. Which eleuation, according to the ancient principles of Iudiciary A≈øtrology, premon≈øtrateth the violeÃÑt depre≈ø≈øion, & gr√©euous oppre≈ø≈øon of the Eccle≈øia≈øtical Iouials by the force of temporal
‚Ä¢ otentats: yea & that ≈øome of them ≈øhall not only be afflicted & tormented, but al≈øo cruellie
‚Ä¢ recuted, and vtterly extingui≈øhed by their
‚Ä¢ ight. For Saturne eleuated aboue Iupiter,
‚Ä¢ n domo mortis, called „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ threateth vnto theÃÑ not only much feare and dread, with the lo≈ø≈øe of ≈øuch goods as their predece≈ø
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ rs enioyed before them, but al≈øo extreme
‚Ä¢ er≈øecution & execution by death. Marry in re
‚Ä¢ ect of circum≈øtances, and certaine credible
‚Ä¢ idicials, I ≈øuppo≈øe that ye Iouials ≈øhal in the
end haue the better day, and triumph ouer the Saturnmes, worthily by the iudgement of the learned. But I define nothing morallie, b√©eing only to ≈øuruey the naturall cau≈øes and ≈øignes of naturall effects. Now for≈øomuch as ≈øome A≈øtrologians ob≈øeruing and regarding only the latitudes of the Planets at the time of their Coniunction, make him to be eleuated aboue the other, who≈øe latitude is eyther more A≈øcentent in Septentrionem, or le≈ø≈øe De≈øcendent ver≈øus Meridiem, (as namelie Ioannes Ganiuerus, who in his booke intituled, Amicus Medicorum, the fir≈øt chapter, and third Difference, making mention of the great Coniunction of Saturne and Iupiter in the 13. grade of Scorpius, which hapned, Anno, 1425. affirmeth that Saturne was then eleuated aboue Iupiter) Why? becau≈øe, as he there alledgeth, Maior fuit illius latitudo ver≈øus SeptentrioneÃÑ, therby gathering and concluding, that much vnwonted trouble and ≈øorrowe ≈øhould follow to the cleargie, and ≈øo ≈øoorth. Now I ≈øay, for the di≈øcu≈ø≈øing of that interpretation, I will heere in like maner ≈øet downe ≈øhe latitudes of the Planets from the Eclyptike line towards the Poles of the Zodiaque at the time of this Coniunction, that it may therby likewi≈øe appeare, whether Saturne be then al≈øo eleuated aboue Iupiter according to his latitude.

Saturne therfore is de≈øcending from the Eclyptike line towards the Antartike pole of the Zodiake 1. grade, 20. Min. wheras Iupiter is de≈øcending from the Eclyptike line towards the Antartike pole of the Zodiake, o. grade, 54. Min. Wherefore Iupiter on the other ≈øide is eleuated aboue Saturne, ≈øecundum latitudinem, bicau≈øe his latitude is le≈ø≈øer than Saturns is. For as when they are both Septentrional A≈øcendent, he is exalted aboue the other, who≈øe latitude is greate≈øt towards the North, (as Ioannes Saxonius te≈øtifieth in the end of his Commentary vpon the fourth difference of Alcabitius his I≈øagoge, ad Magi≈øterium Iudiciorum A≈øtrorum) ≈øo on the contrary part, when they are both Meridional De≈øcendent (as now they are) he mu≈øt n√©eds be eleuated aboue the other, who≈øe latitude is le≈ø≈øer towards ye ≈øouth. So that according to this kind of eleuation, ≈øecundum Latitudinem, the eccle≈øia≈øticall or ≈øpirituall power ≈øhould flouri≈øh and increa≈øe more and more, and their e≈øtate become more
pro≈øperous and fortunate, which is cleane contrarie vnto the A≈øtrologicall iudgement before gathered, and drawen from the eleuation of Saturne aboue Iupiter, ≈øecundum Augem. More therfore now lieth the point of the doubt, whether the eleuation of one Planet aboue another, according to his Aux, or according to his latitude, be mo≈øt effectuall. For the true conclu≈øion, and determination of the premi≈ø≈øes, mu≈øt be drawen from hence. A matter of no ≈ømall difficultie to decide. For mine owne part, touching the credit of Ioannes Ganiuetus, although I ≈øhould liberally graunt that he was, in ≈øacra Theologia, & in ip≈øa A≈øtrologia ≈øuo aeuo facil√® princeps, & ob eandem A≈øtrologiam ab omnibus fer√® Chri≈øtianitatis, & Regibus, & Principibus, nec non ab ip≈øo Pontifice Maximo, haud paruis annuis ≈øtipendijs donatus; (as Gondi≈øaluus Toledo, ≈øereni≈øsimae Francorum Reginae Medicus, Lugdunen≈øi≈ø

great Coniunction of the ≈øuperior Planets, is more notable, yea and more forcible too. then the influence of the Sunnes circular returne, to that indiui≈øible point of the Zodiack from which he fir≈øt digre≈ø≈øed, as ≈øome of the mo≈øt approoued A≈øtrologers affyrme. I ≈øuppo≈øe, that as great and as certaine a te≈øtimony, either of dearth, or of plentifulne≈ø≈øe en≈øuing, may A≈øtrologically be drawen from the ≈øituation and con≈øtitution of the Planets in the cele≈øtiall ≈øcheme, at the time of this rare and ≈øtrange Coniunction, as otherwi≈øe from the po≈øition of the ≈øuperior bodies in the heauenly figure at the Sunnes annuary recour≈øe, A puncto ad punctum ≈øigniferi. For as this famous and memorable meeting of the two ≈øupreme and mo≈øt mighty Planets in the la≈øt face of Pi≈øces, hapneth very ≈øeldome, to wit, but once in the ≈øpace and continuance of 800. yeares, ≈øo when it chaunceth, it commonly cau≈øeth ≈øome ≈øudden changes, and violent alterations, either by meanes of ≈øedition and warres, or con≈øequently by famine and penurie, proceeding of the barrenne≈ø≈øe and ≈øterility of the earth, therby pre≈øaged & progno≈øticated which my brother Richard hath already in my opinion ≈øufficiently confirmed in his Di≈øcour≈øe. Wherfore, I will here now compendiou≈øly, but di≈øtinctly, ≈øet downe the ≈øignifications of tho≈øe parts, drawen partly from the
≈øignes wherein they are placed, but e≈øpecially from the Lords of the ≈øignes, tho≈øe I meane, that haue mo≈øt e≈ø≈øential dignities in ye ≈øame, concluding according to their ≈øituation & con≈øtitution in the prefixed Figure, ≈øiue in Angulo, ≈øiue ≈øuccedenti illi fuerint, ≈øeu cadenti Domo. Withall, regarding their ≈øeuerall a≈øpectes, and mutuall radiatious, as al≈øo whether Dominus domus be come ad locum De≈øcentionis ≈øuae, and ≈øo forth. But I imagine it ≈øhal ≈øuffyce for the pre≈øent, to declare the bare iudgements only, that is, the effectes ≈øignified, by noting in a word, which partes ≈øhalbe Cari precii, which medii, or indifferentis precii, and finally, which humilis, or vilis precii. The cau≈øes and rea≈øons of euery Iudiciall, euery one that is but meanly trauailed in the Principles of A≈øtrologie, may of him ≈øelfe ≈øoone gather, and ea≈øily di≈øcerne: neither do I loue to be verbally tedious, wheÃÑ fewe wordes may as well, or rather better ≈øerue the turne. Which ≈øhort partition may generally ≈øuffice for a competent knowledge of the forenamed parts, vntill they ≈øhall be more diligentlie con≈øidered, and more particularly di≈øcu≈ø≈øed by me, in euery ≈øeuerall y√©ere, as vpon ≈øemblable occa≈øion, I ≈øhall then more ≈øpeciallie ob≈øerue the ≈øame at the Sunnes annuary recour≈øe into the fir≈øt Second of Aries. I haue here ≈øummarily in≈øerted this little, as a briefe te≈øtimonie eyther of dearth or plentifulne≈ø≈øe en≈øuing, drawen onely, as I ≈øaid, from the ≈øituation of the Planets, at the time whereof I now ≈øpeake, but in my y√©erely Almanacke I purpo≈øe, by Gods good leaue, more exactlie, and ≈øo farre as I may po≈ø≈øibly attaine therevnto, more perfectly to examine the ≈øame according to the infallible Rules of this Arte, at the ≈øeueral reuolutions of euery ≈øeueral y√©ere, ≈øo continuing till the effects and operations of this Coniunction ≈øhall fully be accompli≈øhed and ended.

Nowe touching the Con≈øtitution of the ayre, whereof I haue as yet added nothing, for≈øomuche as this famous Coniunction happeneth in Pi≈øces, a ≈øigne of the partition of the watery Trigoni≈øme, I conceiue thereby, that great ≈øtore and abundance of rayne ≈øhall en≈øue, which will cau≈øe many huge inundations, and ouerflowings in ≈øundry places, and that many fierce and boy≈øterous
winds ≈øhall e≈øtfoones breake foorth, the rather al≈øo, becau≈øe both Saturne and Iupiter are then likewi≈øe oriental from the Sunne. Nam Phaenon orientalis e≈øt frigidae complexionis, & humidae item PhaeÃÑton: wherefore much troublous and tempe≈øteous weather is like to be looked for, which is like ≈øo long to continue, how long the one ≈øhall be within the Semidiameter of the other, that is, within nine degr√©es of the other, for the ≈øeuerall Semidiameter of eche of them is 4. degr√©es, 30. minutes, ≈øo that concerning the di≈øpo≈øition of the Ayre, the watery effects of their m√©eting began the 5. day of February la≈øt pa≈øt, this pre≈øent yeere 1583. and ≈øhall endure vntill the 14. day of February next en≈øuing, Anno 1584.

Immediatly after the terme or end of the≈øe effects, Mercury ≈øhall receiue both Saturne and Iupiter: and be corporally conioyned with them, fir≈øt with Saturne, then with Iupiter: which porteÃÑdeth ≈ømal good to ≈øome of the clergie: for Mercury beeing at the time of this Coniunction infortunately ≈øeated in the 9. hou≈øe, and nowe in Coniunction with Saturne and Iupiter, ≈øignifieth the lo≈ø≈øe of their accu≈øtomed tiths, yea and the di≈øplea≈øure of ≈øome noble per≈øonages, or great magi≈øtrates, through who≈øe procurement they are like to be ≈øhrewdly hindered and endamaged.
It ≈øhould ≈øeeme al≈øo that they ≈øhall be xppre≈ø≈øed by meanes of ≈øome Martiall garboyles, and warres, becau≈øe their meeting is in Aries, the diurnall Man≈øion place of Mars.

But as touching the whole continuance of all the≈øe, or ≈øuch other terrible Accidents, and feareful euents, threatned by this grand Copulation of Saturne and Iupiter, fir≈øt progno≈øtically intreated of by my brother Richard in his Di≈øcour≈øe, and nowe enlarged by my ≈øelfe in thie Tractate, I am per≈øwaded that they ≈øhall forcibly begin to take place „Äà‚óä„Äâ in this pre≈øent yeere 1583. For no doubt much ≈øecret villany ≈øhall be committed, much fal≈øe packing v≈øed, much priuy ≈øedition fo≈øtered, and great Martiall furniture, and preparance for warres ≈øhall be heard of, to ≈øome mens co≈øt, euen within the compa≈ø≈øe of this very yeere. Which accordeth with that Maxime of the noble Prince Leopoldus Au≈øtriacus, in the≈øe very words: Annus ip≈øe erit peior in quo Saturnus & Iupiter coniunguntur. But ≈øhall ≈øtill violently continue, and cruelly inuade the inhabitaunts of the earth, vntill ≈øuch time as the one ≈øhall oppo≈øe him≈øelfe again≈øt the other by a diametrall irradiatioÃÑ, which according to the true and daily ≈øphericall motioÃÑs of the≈øe Planets exactly calculated by the excellent Mathematitian Ioannes
Stadius, in his Ephemerides; ≈øhall fall out iu≈øt, Anno Domini 1593. the 21. day of March, about 30. Minuts after thr√©e of the clocke in the after noone. Saturne b√©eing then placed in Cancer, and Iupiter in Capricorne, the one in the 11. hou≈øe, the other in the 5. hou≈øe, as appeareth by the Figure, which I haue here calculated for the very time of their Oppo≈øition, at which time the di≈øtance from the one to the other ≈øhall be 180. Degr√©es.

div.p:
So that the perillous effects of this grand Coniunction ≈øhall continue and ≈øtill increa≈øe on, vntill the accompli≈øhment almo≈øt of ten whole yeeres hereafter en≈øuing, which then ≈øurcea≈øing, the operations of their oppo≈øition ≈øhall begin to worke, beeing in like maner forcibly to take place & perdure till their next Coniunction, which ≈øhall not happen vntill the yeere 1603. the 21 day of December about high noon: at which time they ≈øhal be conioyned agayne in the 10. grade, 26. minute of Sagittary, a ≈øigne of the partition of the fiery Triangularity, and then the Mathematicall circuit beeing fully fini≈øhed, the effects of this Coniunction, and oppo≈øition, ≈øhall togither end, and not before. Etenim effectus durant v≈øque ad reditum, quia nihil datur inane in natura, as is well noted by Cardane. But I am of opinion, that the effects of their oppo≈øition, ≈øhall be more violent and ≈øpeedie, than of this very Coniunction. Nam diametrae radiationes, quemadmodum & Tetragoni≈ømi, mortes repentinas, & violentas mutationes faciunt, CoÃÑ gre≈ø≈øus ver√≤ generalia Accidentia, as one very learnedly iudgeth. And Haly the Arabian in the 8. part, & 6. chapter of his A≈øtrologicall Iudicials, ≈øeemeth to affirme, that, Diametralis coÃÑfiguratio, e≈øt fortior & maioris vigoris, qu√†m vllus alius a≈øpectus; in
writing thus: Scito quod oppo≈øitio Saturni & Martis e≈øt deterior eorum Coniunctione, & deteriores, ac maligniores ≈øignificationes demon≈øtrat. Be≈øide the≈øe, Guido Bonatus in the 13. chapter of his ≈øeconde Treati≈øe, confirmeth the very ≈øame, where he determineth flatly, that Oppo≈øitio e≈øt a≈øpectus vltimatae inimicitiae, vltimatae maliciae, & vltimatae di≈øcordiae; his rea≈øon is, Quia trahitur √¢ Saturno, & √¢ Luminaribus; nam domus Saturni a≈øpiciunt domos Luminarium ab oppo≈øitione: ideoÓÄÇue dicitur i≈øte a≈øpectus perfectae inimicitiae, quo niam Saturnus e≈øt infortunium maius, & fortior caeteris alijs infortunijs. But as concerning this pre≈øent oppo≈øition, it ≈øeemeth extraordinarily malicious, and extremly pernicious, in that they are mo≈øt vnhappily affected, & afflicted, in ca≈øibus, & detrimentis ≈øuis: Quae quidem con≈øtellatio Religioni maximum periculum minatur. A iudgement ouer true. But becau≈øe I purpo≈øe hereafter, if God ≈øpare me life, to di≈øcour≈øe more at large of the≈øe particulars, I wil here only add this one re≈øolute & peremptory iudgement of the great A≈øtrologer, Cyprian de Bohemia; Coniunctiones, oppo≈øitiones, vel eclyp≈øes, in Virg. & Capr. quod in his ≈øignis Iupiter religionis Iudex magnopere debilitetur, mutationes in religione, ≈øacroÓÄÇue ordine
denunciant. Wherfore I will nowe returne againe to the pre≈øent Coniunction, from which I haue a little digre≈ø≈øed. The continuance of whe≈øe effects beeing expre≈ølie declared, it followeth, that we likewi≈øe expre≈øly determine, de ≈øubiectis locis, in what Countries and Cities they ≈øhall e≈øpecially worke, and mo≈øt effectually ≈øhewe them ≈øelues. For Ptolomey ≈øaith, Vnu≈øqui≈øque locus habet ≈øuum ≈øignum & Planetam proprium. And that in re≈øpect of ≈øome other A≈øtrologicall circum≈øtances is the rea≈øon, as Ganiuetus affirmeth, that the plague, or any other noy≈øome and notorious calamitie happeneth in ≈øome one particuler towne or citie, rather then in another, they beeing both ≈øituated in one and the ≈øelfe ≈øame Region. Wherefore concerning the pre≈øent Coniunction, I ≈øuppo≈øe that tho≈øe Realmes and Cities ≈øhall chiefly be vexed and afflicted with the euill influence thereof, which are vnder the partition of the third Quadrangle, that is, vnder the≈øe foure ≈øignes, Gemini, Virgo, Sagittary, Pi≈øces. Vnto which ≈øignes ≈øuch Regions and Cities are ≈øubiect, as are particularly allotted to eche of them, and here ≈øeuerally de≈øcribed as followeth.

Which Figure I haue here purpo≈øely in≈øerted, for that I thinke that citie to be very ≈øubiect to the fore≈øaid great Coniunction, not onely bicau≈øe the ≈øigne A≈øcending in the Horo≈øcope, is the ≈øigne wherin this Coniunction hapneth, but al≈øo becau≈øe certaine other iudgements, which the learned in this facultie may therby ea≈øily gather, touching the ≈øtate of the ≈øaide City, do import as much. In which re≈øpects I tooke it not ami≈ø≈øe to impart the Figure it ≈øelfe to the more particular con≈øideration of ≈øuch, as can, and will take the paines to examine the ≈øame A≈øtrologically.

div.p:
But euen among≈øt the≈øe very nations, countries, Ilands, territories, cities, & townes named and di≈øtingui≈øhed here by me, according to the in≈øtructions of the be≈øt A≈øtrologers, and Co≈ømographers, there is al≈øo a great difference. For tho≈øe per≈øons ≈øhall e≈øpecially be vexed, and oppre≈ø≈øed by this infortunate po≈øition of the cele≈øtiall bodies, in who≈øe Radix, or otherwi≈øe in the annuary profection of the natiuitie, the 21. grade, eyther of Pi≈øces, Sagittary, Virgo, Gemini, Capricorne, or Aquary, is by progre≈ø≈øion A≈øcendent in the Horo≈øcope, or in who≈øe natiuitie, the Sunne, the Moone, or „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ
Geniturae, is re≈øident in the ≈øame grade of any of tho≈øe ≈øignes, or within fiue degr√©es of that grade: for they are mo≈øt like to be ≈øore tormented, and vehemenly di≈øquieted with the troublous affections, and perturbations of the mind, yea and gr√©euou≈ølie afflicted with diuer≈øe noy≈øome and wofull infirmities of the body, which ≈øhall become mortall and peremptory vnto tho≈øe, which haue Saturne thus ill affected vpon the 8. Cu≈øpis, or who≈øe Hylech or Alchocoden, is ill affected in any of the ≈øaid places of the Zodiake.

But they, which in their Radix haue Culmen Medij Coeli, or Pars Fortunae appointed in the ≈øame parts of the Signifier, ≈øhall
≈øuffer in honor, wor≈øhippe, ≈øub≈øtance, and riches, and be vyolently wronged by ≈øome cruell and extraordinary mi≈øchaunces to befall them.

And they moreouer, which haue any of the other ≈øiue erraticall ≈øtarres, as either Mars, Venus, or Mercury, ≈øituated in the ≈øame degree of tho≈øe Signes, ≈øhall by ≈øome mi≈øchieuous meanes or other, be in like manner hindred and indammaged according to the naturall ≈øignification, qualitie, and inclination of each of them ≈øo di≈øpo≈øed.

All and ≈øingular which fore≈øaid euents ≈øhal be multiplyed and increa≈øed, if any hurtfull direction of the natiuine ≈øhall then happen, which doth con≈øent, or any waies accord with this Coniunction. But if any fauourable, and friendly direction ≈øhall come in place, the le≈ø≈øe harme is to be feared, nay in this ca≈øe, directions are alwayes to be preferred before the great Coniunctions, or Oppo≈øitions of the ≈øuperior planets, as al≈øo before the Eclyp≈øes of the Sunne, and Moone, for that their effectes are more forcible and effectuall then the operations of any ≈øuch Copulations, or ob≈øcurations, which worke only as generall cau≈øes, and do therfore hurte tho≈øe men chiefly, who≈øe natiuities accorde with the fir≈øt beginninges or foundations of any ≈øuch Regions, or Cities, as are mo≈øt like to feele and
≈øuffer the cruell influence and terrible operations of any ≈øuch heauenly Accidents.

Here therfore I am to leaue euery man to the con≈øideration of his owne priuate natiuitie, howbeit I could my ≈øelfe rehear≈øe ≈øome of good calling, who≈øe Horo≈øcopes are thus appointed, but that I intend not to become odious, or tedious by this kinde of commemoration, to any particular per≈øon, eyther nowe in this Treati≈øe, or hereafter in any other more learned and painefull Di≈øcour≈øe touching the≈øe or the like poyntes, where notwith≈øtanding they mighte happily ≈øerue to a greater purpo≈øe, and farther v≈øe, then nowe pre≈øently they may, for proofe and triall of the fore≈øaide euentes, as they ≈øhall afterwardes fall out more effectually. But I am growen ≈øomewhat longer, then I purpo≈øed in the beginning, and therefore will heere drawe towardes an ende, mo≈øte heartily committing euery man, to the ≈øerious care and regarde of his owne ≈øafetie, and con≈øequently to the tuition of the omnipotent Adonay, who of his infinite and ≈øingular mercies and goodnes, graunt, that we which nowe liue for a time, may in time ≈øo liue to the true and ≈øincere wor≈øhippe of him that liueth for euer and euer, that by ≈øo liuing wee maye learne to dye, and by ≈øo
dying liue with him for euermore. Sub Lunae ≈øecundo Gabriele, variae hominibus impo≈øitae ≈øunt leges, veri Dei cultus negligitur, fal≈øorum Deorum religio nimis propagatur, as Ioannes Tritemius wryteth of that age in his booke de ≈øeptem Secundeis, And doeth it not behoue vs to take carefull heede, and beware in time, le≈øt a newe Ioannes Tritemius, or ≈øome other of greater credite hereafter ari≈øe, to di≈øcredite this our lo≈øt age, ≈øub lunae tertio Gabricle, with the like report, for neglecting the ≈øacred and ioy≈øul tidings of the go≈øpel, which being neuer ≈øo plentifully taught, was neuer more ≈øcantly learned, and being neuer ≈øo truely preached, was neuer more fal≈øly followed, or more lightly regarded, then now generally it is. The more pre≈øent ≈øhame, the more future puni≈øhment. What maruell therfore though ≈øuch plagues hang ouer our heades? What maruell though Gods vengeance be at hand, nay even now ready to fal downe vpon vs, to oppre≈ø≈øe, and con≈øume vs? What maruell though the ordinarie cour≈øe, as wel of all naturall, as of morall things be quite turned top≈øie turuie?

div.p:
In which Progno≈øtical Epigrame, Hieronimus Wolfius, whom our Ma≈øter A≈øchame in his di≈øcour≈øe of Germaine affaires, calleth his very friend, and who≈øe excellent learning partly by his Tran≈ølations, and explications of Demo≈øthenes, and Ipocrates, partly by his other as well A≈øtrologicall, as Philo≈øophicall, and humanity writings, is famou≈øly knowen ouer all Europe. In which Propheticall Epigrame, I ≈øay, this learned man hath truely de≈øcribed, and as it were liuely painted out the wicked peruer≈øity & peruer≈øe wickednes of this age: with a nece≈ø≈øary inuectiue
again≈øt the abu≈øes, and enormities now raigning: by conferring and comparing the ≈øame with the manifold tokens and miracles A≈øtrologically progno≈øticated, touching the future mo≈øt mi≈øerable e≈øtate, and condition of the world, which ≈øhall ≈øhortly no doubt more ≈øen≈øibly appeare, to the terror and a≈øtoni≈øhment of all rea≈øonable Creatures then liuing. I meane not here to recapitulate the horrors of the marueilous yeere, 1588. or to vnfolde other auncient predictions, & prophecies, in which, Conclu≈øio, as we ≈øay in Logick, Semper ≈øequitur deteriorem partem, I would to God, the ≈øhadowe of the earth, and earthly things, did not take away the cleare light of the Sunne from vs, and cau≈øe an horrible Eclyp≈øe in vs. Lord, that euery man would priuately contend to amend one, and both priuately and publikely pray for the amendement of all. How ≈øoone would God be moued to deale with vs, as he did by the Niniuites, who≈øe puni≈øhment, vpon their vnfained repentance was differred long beyonde the compa≈ø≈øe of the 40. dayes, prophetically forethreatened by Ionas? And did it not plea≈øe God to prolong the life of king Ezechias for the ≈øpace of 15. yeeres, notwith≈øtanding that the Prophet I≈øaias had progno≈øticated his death, as at hand within one day? Other examples might be alledged, to ≈øhew that puni≈øhments
decreed from aboue, are in ≈øome part alterable, vpon humble ≈øignification of a contrite and reformed heart: Which God graunt to all his elect, and namely to vs in England, whome he hath ≈øo graciou≈øly indued with ≈øo many, and ≈øo long enduring felicities. For the pro≈øperous continuance, and perfection whereof, my final wi≈øh, and prayer is, as I haue compry≈øed the ≈øame, in the≈øe foure rude, but hartie ver≈øes:

div.head: The Conclu≈øion.
div.p: NOwe good Brother, as in the beginning of this treati≈øe, I addre≈ø≈øed my preface vnto you, ≈øo hauing thus ≈øupplied ≈øuch Additions, as I thought requi≈øite to bee annexed to my brother Richards A≈øtrologicall Di≈øcour≈øe, I am here in the end to committe, or rather ≈øubmitte the ≈øame, as wel to your iudgement for reformation, as to the Cen≈øure of our learned≈øt A≈øtrologers, for allowance or di≈øalowance. The only fauour I require at their handes, is this, that they would iudge as they finde, without any ≈øpice of parciality, which oftentimes corrupteth, eueÃÑ the ≈øounde≈øt iudgements otherwi≈øe. I would be loath to attribute, or arrogate too much vnto my≈øelfe: let other determine for me, or again≈øt me, as with indifferency, grounded vpon rea≈øonable ≈økill, they ≈øhall ≈øee occa≈øion.

I was here purpo≈øed to haue taken my leaue; But ≈øeeing it hath bene my good hap, (for ≈øo I interprete it) ≈øince my ≈øupplement of the former additions, to light vpon two new bookes, ≈øpecially concerning the≈øe matters, the one a French Almanacke, or rather di≈øcour≈øe of certaine A≈øtrologicall Accidents, either lately hapned, or ≈øhortly to happen: the
other a progno≈øticall iudgement of one Robert Tanner, touching the fore≈øaid Coniunction, I am bold to trouble you a ittle longer, with a note or two, concerning them. As for the French di≈øcour≈øe, I can ≈øay the le≈ø≈øe for my ≈ømall ≈økil in French, yet thus farre dare I pre≈øume vpon the very Title, or In≈øcription, thereof, that Docteur Francois Liberati de Rome, is none of the perfecte≈øt A≈øtrologers, either in Italy, or in France. For in naming le 2, Iour de May, for the time of the Grand Coniunction, he ≈øheweth him ≈øelf ouermuch addicted to his ma≈øter Cyprian de Bo√´mme, who contenteth him ≈øelfe with Alphon≈øus Calculation, whereas according to Stadius, a more exacte and ab≈øolute Mathematitian, following the mo≈øt perfect Rules of Prolomy, and Copernicus, it is certainly to happen vpon the 28. of April, which my brother Richard & I haue therfore re≈øolutely ≈øet down, notwith≈øtaÃÑding our knowledge of Leouitius & Me≈øtlinus difference. Marry he promi≈øeth to make an amends, in his Ephemerides, and di≈øcour≈øe of the reformation of the yeere, and of the Pa≈øque: which I may hap expect a good while yet, if he hold the right veyne of ≈øome Italians. In the meane while, ≈øee how his la≈øt iudgement iumpeth with ours, for the cour≈øe and ≈øtate of the yeere pre≈øent, Et finablement
‚Ä¢ An. 1583. ≈øera pluuieux, & dangereux pour lee
biens de la terre, et an≈øsi repentini tumultus et apparatus belli. And therefore we are hartily to wi≈øh, & pray with him, Dieu par ≈øa mi≈øericorde nous delieure du mal et du danger que par les A≈øtres, nous ≈øommes menazes, & nous enuoye la paix, & la≈øainct grace. Which is al that I am pre≈øently to note touching the contents of that French di≈øcour≈øe. Now as for old Tanners Progno≈øtical iudgemeÃÑt, who intituleth him≈øelfe a ≈øtudent in A≈øtrology, and Co≈ømography, he were the rather to be borne withall, if his ignorance and ≈øimplicitie, ≈øauoured not ≈øo much of ≈øelfe lyking. I cannot but maruaile, that hauing ≈øeene the other Di≈øcour≈øe, he was not a≈øhamed to put foorth his: wherin his only labor in a manner is, to ≈øet downe his ≈øchemes in letters, being before de≈øcrybed in Figures. For what is all the re≈øt, but a mingle mangle of ≈øtealths, and patcheries out of Leouitius, Rogers ≈øecond comming of Chri≈øt, the French Almanack, and my Brothers Di≈øcour≈øe, out of which, hee hath more then once, or twi≈øe culled out whole ≈øides verbatim, without any mention of him, together with certaine iudgementes of Stadius, applyed without all iudgement, in referring the ≈øame to no other Meridian, then that, which the ≈øaid Stadius re≈øpected in his calculation for the latitude of Anwerpe. And alas, what other iudgements
are in that ≈øily Pamphlet, whereof it ≈øhould beare the name of A Progno≈øticall iudgement? Truly were it not, that his pretended de≈øire and zeale to doo good, may ≈øeeme ≈øome way to excu≈øe him, the ≈øimple old ≈øtudent in A≈øtrology, and Co≈ømography, were otherwi≈øe to be handled for his ≈øimple young labour, then I will here ≈øpeake of. Which neuerthele≈ø≈øe I write not ≈øo much to di≈øgrace him, or to credite my ≈øelfe, as to adui≈øe the di≈øcret Reader not to ≈øuffer him ≈øelfe to be abu≈øed by any ≈øuche glo≈øes of good intention, but to ≈øu≈øpend his iudgement vpon triall, before he re≈øolue vpon tru≈øt. The olde fellowe may perhaps beare him ≈øelfe vpon his experience, as it is ≈øaid he ch√©efly doth: but as reading can do little without rea≈øonable good experience, ≈øo experience cannot do very muche without rea≈øonable good reading: which to ≈øay troth, ≈øeemeth to be farre from this wofull Progno≈øticall Iudge. And that which is mo≈øte of all, he concealeth their names, to whom he is mo≈øt beholding: and publi≈øheth that for his owne, which God wot he hath litle right or title vnto. You know who affirmeth, Ingenui Animi e≈øt, profiteri per quos profeceris: and may not my brother ≈øay to this olde Co≈ømographer, as Tully doth in one place? Tu, qui a Naeuio vel ≈øump≈øi≈øti multa, ≈øi fateris: vel, ≈øi negas, ≈øurripui≈øti.
But God, and the world forgiue him, as we do: and let both him and all other account of vs no otherwi≈øe, then they find vs in very d√©ed: which I am ≈øure is your chiefe de≈øire. I might ea≈øily enlarge this Epiloge with interlacing of other matters: and namely touching Hermes mo≈øt learned Iatromathematica, and my Tran≈ølation thereof, annexed to the pre≈øent Treati≈øe, for certaine good con≈øiderations: but to auoyde tediou≈ønes, as well vnto you, as vnto euery other curteous Reader, I will here cea≈øe from interrupting your weightier ≈øtudies, and mo≈øt hartily commit them, and your ≈øelfe vnto God: with like commendations from all our friends in Walden, Stan≈øted, and Mayners.
